Re: Gluteus Maximus and increased protein consumption because it allows our pelvis to pivot; one of my professors, Paul Bingham, linked them to a different reason than running, to throw objects with lethal force. With bipedalism, the rotator cuff, which allows us to throw overhand instead of underhand, another trait unique to humans, and our ability to pivot our pelvis, we could not only toss objects, but throw rocks and spears for hunting and self-defense. He argued our ability to hunt from range (again, unique to humans) is the key to us eventually having enough excess resources to develop bigger brains, and later on avoid oppression (a child can kill an adult with a rock, while a lion cub is at the mercy of its parents) to set up societies that were more complex than "I am the biggest, so I lead." This positive feed back looped, as after we gave up hunting and gathering, women could gestate for 9 months, leading to more altricial offspring.

The theory, I think, explains human anatomy extremely well. Big lower body muscles and sweating is definitely indicators that we chase prey to exhaustion, but throwing explains why we have good eye sight (identifying snakes are another explanation for eyesight), are bipedal and have rotator cuffs. I don't even know if being bipedal is actually better for marathon running, it's not particularly aerodynamic, and it doesn't necessarily always increase surface area for cooling, but this is just me speculating. I think being furless and sweating is much more important. If we were exclusively power scavengers or exhaustion based hunters, the link to increased brain development, greater visual acuity and particularly the rotator cuff would continue to remain a mystery, imo. I think we were able to become dominant cause we could do all, attack from range, chase down, or steal the kill in case someone else beat us to it, and I think our evolution is multi-faceted; we were responding to all the variables, not just one.

Dang I was really hoping you guys would talk about or at least mention the fact that not all earwax is actually… waxy?

While most people have and are thus only familiar with the most common kind of earwax - aka wet earwax - there is also another type that is most commonly found in people of (East) Asian or Native American descent - dry earwax. Dry earwax as it’s name implies is dry and flaky, but one of the most fascinating things about the whole dry vs wet earwax thing imo is its correlation to body odor; those with wet earwax (roughly 98% of the human population) produce body odor, while those with dry ear wax do not.

As someone whose always had dry earwax and no b.o. (or so I’ve been told) who always secretly wondered if I truly didn’t have b.o. or if I just couldn’t smell it, so learning about the actual genetic/biological science behind it and the link between earwax and b.o. was especially interesting to me.

“Of course, people with wisdom teeth would have to die, and not breed, in order to not pass on that gene.”  I actually disagree with you here.  There is a phenomenon whose name I do not know, where offspring respond to the environmental conditions of the parents.  One example would be an experiment where a generation of chickens were fed nothing but live hard-shelled insects, mostly beetles if memory serves.  As most of you know, chickens don’t have teeth. They use an organ called a gizzard to grind up food before it is passed to the stomach.  There is normally zero reason for a chicken to grow teeth.  However, hard-shelled insects are difficult to grip with a smooth chicken bill.  Oddly, most of the offspring of the chickens in this experiment were hatched with serrated surfaces on the inside edge of their bills, making it much easier to catch and hold the hard-shelled insects.

On the subject of wisdom teeth and jaw size:
I have always speculated that the my family’s larger jaw size may have something to do with our diet. I grew up on a cattle ranch in Montana in the Eighties and Nineties, and let me tell you there were some lean years. We grew our own vegetables and ate the cattle that were too injured to save. There were some REALLY good steaks, and also some incredibly tough ones. The veggies were sometimes terrific, sometimes stunted and woody. I recall a number of times that I paused eating, not because I wasn’t hungry , but because my jaw was too tired to continue chewing.
Our family dentist insisted on pulling my lower wisdom teeth as soon as they crowned around age 19. (Like my father, I never developed upper wisdom teeth or adult eye teeth).
Now, I occasionally cut up my lower gums because of the lack of matching molars. I have to chew with an underbite to match molars in the back of my mouth.
On a side note, I still resent my dentist for insisting on pulling my oversized baby eye teeth so he could replace them with virtually identical implants. I have to floss after every meal to remove the food particles that accumulate under the implant caps.

I can tell you that a good friend of mine counseled me to NEVER shave the butt hair.  He said that his wife’s preference for hairless nethers resulted in both chafing and a small fungal infection, due to trapped moisture.  To be fair, he was a Marine at the time, running 20 to 40 miles a week.

Butt hair:
Theory 4; Cushion and warmth. Comfortable and soft seats are a relatively new invention for humans to use. Before that, we sat on logs, rocks, dirt, and other such items. Butt hair provides slight cushion to those rigid items, but also adds a barrier of nerveless keratin to protect our skin from cold temperatures. Us with hairy butts have no problem sitting on the toilet seat that hasn't been touched for hours. Meanwhile, the hirsute deprived quiver from the momentary shock of ice cold plastic or porcelain touching their rears.

Theory 5; Filter. Just like the rest of our orifices, they are surrounded or covered by hair to keep small particles from entering. Our anus is usually an "exit only", but sitting in the dirt, on mossy rocks, decaying logs... there were high chances of critters and bacteria navigating its way into the anus. The hair would be a protection against that.

So, butt hair, while fashionably disgusting today, may have 5 different jobs that are still useful today.

Elephants do NOT have more than two sets of teeth. It is just that the adult teeth originate at the back of the jaw. One at a time, they move forward into chewing position. Only one tooth at a time in the stream is in use. [two sides of two jaws make 4 active teeth.] When the last set of 4 is worn out and becomes unusable, the elephant cannot chew its food and then dies of starvation even though food is plentiful, because elephants cannot digest food that has not been properly chewed.

Hyraxes are NOT rodents, but are more closely related to the Proboscidea (elephants and their extinct relatives) and Sirenia (manatees and dugongs). Their rodent-like appearance is due to convergent evolution.

I wouldn't call goosebumps useless. 1) They are kinda of like Spider-mans's "spider-sense" right? Almost like a subconcious alert your body sends for your brain to notice something you couldn't detect with your supposed 5 senses. 2) Goosebumps help keep the body warm. When someone is cold the tiny muscles on each hair folicle will contract which is what causes the hairs to stand erect. This helps trap air and create what is referred to as "dead air". Dead air is air that has been trapped and contained, or at least is not moving. Even the hairs on your arm, even if you don't have alot of hair, help to trap or slow air. The air in between your layers of clothes would also be considered "dead air". By maintaining this barrier of dead NON-MOVING air that surrounds your body it allows your body to heat up said air and in turn the air helps to keep you warm and maintain body temperature and form, like I said, a temperature barrier, or more accurately a buffer.

Even if something is know to be factual, if this information is obscure or you're presenting it to an audience that may not know what you're informing us about you should present your evidence for the things you're telling us. If you're creating educational content or your claim something to be factual you must present evident for that or you risk making your claim far less valid than thy otherwise would be. There is plenty of information in this video that logically made sense to me and I thought to myself "Well that seems obvious / self explanatory / accurate" . There’s a mistake when you mentioned the wisdom teeth come in and “crowd out” other teeth. This is an outdated idea that has been pretty thoroughly disproven in the orthodontic literature. Yes, they can come in impacted (sideways) and definitely cause problems back there, but the idea that they can push and create enough force to cause crowding in the front teeth simply isn’t true. There’s way too many teeth in between that disperse the wisdom tooth eruption pressure- the pressure is dissipated after at most, the first molar. Teeth are a pain in the ass to move, and the eruption force generated isn’t that strong. This is like saying you can stand behind your house and push on the back wall and cause the front wall of the house to move. Way too much anchorage in between.

The real cause is “late mandibular growth”, which is a minor but normal growth period of the lower jaw experienced in late-adolescence/early adulthood (same time the wisdom teeth are coming in). The lower jaw grows down and forward, taking the roots of your lower incisors (front teeth) along for the ride. Since the tops of these teeth are trapped behind the upper incisors, the overall result is a tipping backwards (towards the tongue) of those teeth, causing them to overlap. The degree to which people experience this late mandibular growth varies, but it’s a normal process that happens to everyone. It’s why even people who get their wisdom teeth removed as teenagers will get this same type of lower incisor crowding in early adulthood, which many people attribute to orthodontic relapse or not wearing their retainers. This is still a widely believed myth, especially among dentists (most know little about orthodontics) or older orthodontists who haven’t stayed current with the literature. It was accepted as fact for decades, but many recent and thorough longitudinal growth studies show it’s definitely late mandibular growth causing the problems, not wisdom teeth. Most people should still get their wisdom teeth out though for the other problems they can cause (very difficult/borderline impossible to clean- or fix if you do get a cavity, impacted ones can cause gum/bone infections or resorb the roots of the second molars, etc)

Source: I’m a Orthodontist.

The issue with wisdom teeth is not just due to the jaw getting shorter.  There is another factor at work.  In the past, humans were expected to loose many teeth during their lifetimes, through accidents, fights, and dental issues.  Crowding was partially mitigated by having fewer overall teeth.  Then we invented dentistry, so more people got to keep their teeth, and thus, even more crowding.

The third eyelid is present in dogs and cats, too.  If your dog is really relaxed sometimes you can see their third lid partially closed, and it also closes when they have a foreign body in their eye, or a scratch or ulcer on the surface, to cover and protect the eye.  Dogs have a gland on the underside of the third eyelid that produces tears, and sometimes it can pop out from under the lid to make a pink bump in a condition called Cherry Eye.  They used to remove the gland then, but now we know how important it is in producing tears, so we just tuck it back under the lid and have a few ways to suture it back in place.

Dogs have more crooked and overlapping teeth the smaller their jaws get. When we breed for flatter faces and/or smaller jaws, the jaw shrinks much faster than the teeth do, so small dogs have proportionally much bigger teeth than big dogs with normal jaws have. There's less bone surrounding the tooth roots, so any dental disease that eats away at the bone around the root will be that much more significant. A tooth root abscess around the lower canine or first molar in a shih tzu can lead to a broken jaw!
